job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Wilmington, NC
pros: I get paid and I like the team I work with.
cons: The pay is bad. The benefits are poor. They hardly cover anything and out of pocket is too high. They only allow 1 week FMLA to care for spouse. This is ridiculous. Senior management talks out of both sides of their face- can't be trusted. They are a business not a hospital. They don't care about their employees. Make them work short and tell the media they are full staffed. Not true. For every person they hire 1 to 2 leave. Plus, it takes awhile for that person to be trained. They are focus on untrained nurses giving them bonuses but do nothing for the experienced nurses that are there with the knowledge to train them. So they leave, and only barely trained nurses are there for an entire floor. It is unsafe. Patient care has greatly suffered. I do the best that I can, but I know I no longer can give the best care that I once gave because the workload is just too great. I'm waiting on my turn to leave. There is no one working in supply room at night so if we need something we are out of luck unless the nursing supervisor can find it. If she's lucky.

pros: My coworkers were the best part of my job, but aside from that there wasn’t much else.
cons: They expected us to take 7-8 patients at once, staffing was horrible and the pay did not compare to the work they expected RN’s to put in. Not to mention, they had literally no aides whatsoever so the nurse was expected to do both jobs and care for that many patients at one time. Oh and they will request you to work OT as much as they possibly can get out of you because they have no staff. I’ve worked at 7 hospitals in my time and have never had such a bad experience like what I experienced here. I really hope things change for the better.

pros: Entry level competitive salary, will hire new EMTs
cons: Middle management can’t help you. They are who you report to yet they have no power.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Wilmington, NC
pros: I enjoy working for a trauma center and the experiences that it brings.
cons: Constantly understaffed despite what admin says. Every single shift they rob Peter to pay Paul. Very deceptive. Pay is low but the CEO just got a 1.7M bonus and the doctors get free catered meals in the physician lounge every single day. Mass exodus of nurses & staff going on for months now and they just up and cut all travelers from the staff despite us already working extremely short. They say they are broke but we don't buy it. The truth is this nursing shortage isn't a crisis, it's a strategy. And a very profitable one.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Wilmington, NC
pros: Overall, the floor staff (nurses, cnas, techs, etc.) were awesome. For the most part, they have some really great nurses that were always willing to help the best they could. As long as the team could work together, things ran smoothly.
cons: Management is sub-par at best. CNAs are consistently short-handed, no matter how many people they claim to hire. In a typical shift, there were 1-2 CNAS to 40+ patients, and many times other floors or staffing would steal CNAS from the floor to staff other areas, leaving 1 CNA to 40+ patients. Staffing ratios are severely unsafe, which directly contributed to many incidents. The pay is well below the national average, and a slap in the face compared to the amount of work and responsibility involved. Dare ask for more staff or better conditions or pay, it's practically a running joke to management that staffing ratios are unsafe. During the sale, Managers left their positions in droves, a huge red flag. What they tell the public is vastly different than what is really happening on the inside.

This has caused the loss of that close-knit, small community hospital environment and more of a larger corporation environment. This has led to many great staff members leaving the organization.

pros: Free parking. Employee pharmacy. Employee health clinic. Very good co-workers.  Majority of hospital workers are pleasant.  Clean, environment. Wonderful patient population. Currently has pension plan.
cons:
Required to work overtime but sent home when census a little low.( treated like day laborers not like the professionals we are). Frequently work understaffed. Poor response to unit needs by upper management. Horrible computer charting program limits the nurses ability to accurately document patient events.
Required to complete mandatory continuing education on days off. No regard for personal time.
Benefits constantly decreasing for staff while upper management receives better benefits and large bonuses. My take home pay is the same as it was 10 years ago due to increased cost of benefits. This is in spite of raises and 1-2% merit raises.
HR out of touch with what is happening in actual health care setting.  Senior exit interviewer stated she had never been on my unit. Stated no awareness of above issues.

review_title: Thier lure is beach life, WATCH OUT for NHRMC
pros: lately, with the theory by upper management that employees are expendable, there is a prevailing attitude by management that we RN's are "lucky " to be working at NHRMC. Ive was currently employed there for over 6 years and was told by my director when asking about staff shortages-"you can leave if not satisfied", and this was at the start of the supposed open door policy meeting.
cons: down sides- 1) The common RN ratio's are 7 or 8 patients to one RN, although they say its not guaged by that, it's supposedly guaged by "productivity hours". which simply means that if your not busting you ass, then your sent home to use accumulated PDO days.- there are many more downsides, but that is the main one above BEWARE of this hospital.

job_title: Patient Experience Representative in Wilmington, NC
pros: Worked at Cape Fear Cancer Specialists. The majority of the people I worked with, having direct access to management 90% of the time.  I had no problem speaking with management about my needs, and they were always very flexible. THE PATIENTS! The patients kept me going and are rockstars. Also had great access to the doctors and most are more than happy to educate and and answer questions regarding medical aspects of the disease.
cons: Pay is not great for the education I had and was working towards. Management tended to do sneaky stuff like fire someone and pretend it never happened. The people that were fired when I was employed there had been there for over 10 years and helped grow the company, and it seemed they were cruelly weasled out of job slowly, almost trying to force them to quit. Again, I was not apart of those people, as I had to leave due to school and their inability to hire me on part time instead. But those were rumors and what I had seen.

pros: No layoffs in years (I've only been here 3 years). Incentives for working extra. Tuition assistance after only 90 days of employment. Nice employee gym. I've worked in 2 specialty departments and the transition from one to another was easy. Willing to hire with little experience and train on the job. Management was very friendly and down to earth in the two departments I have worked in. One department orientation was fantastically organized and the other was very unorganized and more "day to day" agenda or calendar.
cons: Lower pay, short staffing, so will get asked to work non stop one week but then may float the next week due to low census. Have had some issues butting heads with MDs but that's probably anywhere. Scheduling issues (some department specific, others hospital wide) have caused experienced nurses to leave, resulting in less experienced nurses running the unit.

review_title: LOVE the people I work with, very dissatisfied with the company
pros: The insurance, my coworkers, single patient rooms, free parking for staff.
cons: I felt as though I was lied to at orientation. They spoke about how much they care about their employees and since I have been there I feel very underappreciated by management and providers, and many of my fellow nurses feel the same way as well. They continue to put on more work and responsibility (I.e. we are now 7:1 even on days which I find horrific especially now that we are entering flu and pneumonia season) yet the raises are minimal and benefits are not really that great. I was told that we were to get a "generous" sum of money to go back to school, which turned out to be on $2,000 a year---which would probably barely cover text books. I also feel like it costs an arm and a leg to request time off.

job_title: Executive Director RN in Wilmington, NC
pros: Paid for classes and certs. Clinical staff has amazing team members. Lifelong friends made here on the battlefield.  Great medical benefits
cons: Disconnected management, do not communicate with employees. Continually change procedures to make it look good on paper while making it ever more dangerous for patients and your license. Huge turnover rate related to inept leadership. The clinical staff feels like a front line infantry with no communications to base.  The feeling is the department is covering up and we were blatantly told to change chart times to meet standards.  A sentinel event occurred a few years ago and the continuous changes to procedure have made it more and more dangerous. Staff have zero departmental support and fear for their jobs daily. The dept continues to have new grads come in and have one year nurses orient them: more danger.

job_title: Lean Project Lead II in Wilmington, NC
pros: Senior leadership is driven and has gotten better about having a focus.  Benefits cannot be beat!!!!  :o)  Employees care and are engaged in their work.  Performance improvement has gotten better over the past 5 years as a direct result of the organization practicing Lean Methodology.
cons: No diversity among upper management.  About 7% of the leadership is non-Caucasian.  Women in leadership is well represented and diversity among the the residency program is present.  Opportunities for Black, Latino, Asian, and other races is not statistically divided or represented among the 200+ management and above positions, especially among the senior team.

pros: Great teamwork.  The people I worked with made the job.  Even the coordinators and the manager were amazing.  Great opportunities to expand/move to another unit.  Additional education provided frequently.  Great learning experience.  Doctors on the unit were easy to talk to.
cons: Too many patients per nurse at times.  Overwhelming.  On a unit with the majority being new nurses.  At times, all new nurses making the floor feeling overwhelmed.  Certain "bad seed" employees, when discussed with management, sometimes little was ever done.

pros: There was a time when I loved it here. The benefits were fabulous, the team I worked with was wonderful and I easily saw myself finishing my career here in North Carolina.
cons: But then things changed. My particular department underwent some management changes, and they were NOT for the better. The whole dynamic of the department changed and instead of co-workers being supportive and helpful towards one another, they became two-faced, competitive and unkind. Favoritism ensued, staffing suffered, and if you opened your mouth to express distaste or concern, you immediately became labeled as a problem. (When you're sitting in orientation and they tell you they want to hear of your experiences/ideas from other hospitals, don't believe them...) Grateful that I made my escape away from the bedside...

job_title: Patient Support Representative in Wilmington, NC
pros: Meet some really nice patients and a handful of new friends.
cons: Stay away from the outpatient offices. They are dreadful. There is no empathy or rapport given by administration. And these offices are run by bratty women that try to insert themselves into your lives because that can't stand living their own.

review_title: In hindsite, I would never have moved to Wilmington, NC
pros: The people I worked with were professional, caring, educated and hard working.  We worked closely as a team and always covered each other.  This is not so true of other floors.
cons: There is only one hospital to work for here in this town and they own most of the outlying facilities also, so they corner the market and are able to dictate salaries.  Most of the NURSES live under the poverty level and are only able to make due by having a second job.

pros: Overall a happy place to work, secure jobs, overall positive attitude with consistent growth
cons: If you aren't a nurse or a doctor, you are treated pretty poorly. Management tries to make as few people as possible do as large of a job as possible. Very short staffed but management refuses to create new positions to keep the hospital in the black

job_title: Director of Operationa in Hampstead, NC
pros: Highly evolving organization. I genuinely loved coming to work everyday. I had a boss I respected it understood the growing pains of a new physician network. I found my boss (VP) to be highly ethical and very much in touch with the reality of patient satisfaction and exemplary care. I loved my job here but needed to explore the other side of healthcare from an IT / technology perspective. NHRMC gave me the tools and confidence to do that.
cons: Not enough arms or legs for the volume of work. Although professional development was available I was often unable to take advantage of it just because I was so busy maintaining my day to day responsibilities.

pros: NHRMC has good benefits and a pension plan.  It used to have a wonderful atmosphere that made you want to come to work.
cons: The atmosphere has changed so much here, that I've witnessed people quitting because of it,    What would otherwise be a wonderful place to work is being undermined by some of the mid lvl management  in place.

job_title: Company Police Officer in Wilmington, NC
pros: Lots of state training opportunities, yearly raise opportunities up to 4%, cheap insurance, pay differentials for nights and weekends, provides overtime instead of comp time unlike some departments
cons: No 401k/403b matching investment, few opportunities for advancement, not great insurance coverage, difficult to get replacement gear or uniforms, poor command climate, no policies or procedures to guide you in doing your job, on call system that requires you be available for 12 hours but paid for 2

review_title: An excellent place to learn a lot as a chaplain resident
pros: This employer is good to employees
cons: It is difficult to get hired

pros: Benefits are great. Yearly evals offer monetary growth opportunitues. The org is really stepped up in the community to be leaders in health care equity not just equality that makes me proud to work there. Health care, just like a bike, is not a ive size fits all. (Jack Barto is no longer CEO, I'm rating John Gizdic)
cons: Everyone is not treated equally. If you are a grade A employee you will get more and more work until you're in the verge of breaking while others sit and do nothing or barely work their hours.

pros: Patient safety is priority.  Very supportive and compassionate manager.  Employee fitness center and a philosophy of work-life balance.  Great benefits!
cons: Hiring new staff takes a long time, but projects and workload don't decrease.  Expected to manage several priorities and tasks and meet tight deadlines, so work-life balance is difficult to achieve.  Jack Barto retired and new CEO.

pros:
Been here 15 years and wouldn't go anywhere else! And I have worked in other healthcare facilities... There's no comparison! 
The culture created over the years in this organization is phenomenal! People smile in the hallways and say hello to each other, there's a genuine feeling of team work for the common goal of providing the best care possible no matter what department you work for.
cons: None! If there was any issue I feel wholeheartedly that the leadership would listen and actually take my concerns to heart.

job_title: Behavioral Management Sitter in Wilmington, NC

review_title: Short staffed for over two years.
pros: Great benefits; PDO add up quick, health/vision/eye insurance at a fair rate. Awesome team of clinical staff in all nursing departments.
cons: Short staffed, heavy workload because of this. Constantly getting floated to other units/floors causing much frustration. Low pay compared to the cost of living. Small yearly raises (.01- .10 cents) Have to schedule your days off and PDO at a minimum of two months in advance. Impossible to travel during holidays, you either work Christmas Eve or Christmas for example.

pros: The upper management seems to care, but like all other nursing positions, there is a high nurse to patient ratio.  Always makes it difficult to make patients happy when you have greater than 5 patients, all with a high acuity.
cons: Middle management seen disconnected.  Often times, the floor managers are no where to be found, and wouldn't dream about offering direct patient care when a nurse is busy.

pros: “You get to live at the beach’
cons: The mentioned “pros” are what they tell you when you ask why such low pay. Company has changed from a person centered to business model. Team work changed to bosses and hired pay.  People employed there are great, but pressure to bring in the dollar has resulted in a stressful environment and lack of genuine concern for helping those in need.

pros: The area that it is in.
cons: There are people in management positions that have no business being there, It's all about who you know.  Be really careful about being lured here.  If something doesn't work out there are virtually no other places to work.

review_title: But you get the beach bonus......
pros: It is the only hospital in town and also owns most of the doctor's offices. Good insurance.
cons: Too many to list.  Low pay, Under staffed, no respect for employees. Sacrifices on patient care in the name of cost.

pros: NHRMC provides a wonderful environment for employees to do their best.  Work-life balance is a high priority, as is ensuring the financial and educational future of their employees.  It is a family environment.  I have never seen so many employees in one organization at or above the 20, 30, and even 40 year mark.  They provide wonderful care to their patients, the community, and their staff.
cons: I can think of no cons.

review_title: Wonderful hospital, with great benefits and just culture.
pros: Great benefits, wonderful hospital fitness center, friendly staff and excellent management.  Wilmington is a wonderful place to live (At the beach) and they offer flexible scheduling (self-scheduling), which is great for staff morale.  Wonderful doctors and it is a teaching hospital.
cons: They seem to always be short staffed.  There are no other hospitals in town, so no competition=Pay lower than many of NC hospitals.

pros: I absolutely love working here. The department I work in was very helpful in training and was glad to answer any questions I had. I've met the CEO once and he seems to really care for his people, down to earth guy. Wish I would have applied to work here sooner.
cons: Not a con with the company, more like the employees. You try and smile walking down the hallway and most staff will ignore you. Smile people :)

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Wilmington, NC
pros: RN staff is wonderful, hardworking and loyal
cons: Over the years....less input by Nurses, Everything is punitive and the customer is ALWAYS right. I have repeatedly watch bad behavior rewarded by management. Also, all the money goes to the CEO and VP's. does NOT trickle down. Have not received a raise that keeps up with inflation in years! many days 12 hrs with no lunch.  would you want me taking care of you?

pros: There are so many different areas to choose from. The hospital has every kind of nursing you can imagine from geriatrics to neonates. There's something for everyone.
cons: The only downfalls are 12 hour shifts and having to work holidays and weekends.

pros: Stable organization, clear management goals from the c-suite, strong fiscal position compared to any nationally ranked Hospital (Small and large), great benefits and great cost of same, overall a great organization.
cons: average to slightly lower than average pay scale.  promote from within, but don't offer great pay jumps for advancement, unless your coming from outside the organization.

review_title: Worked 3 years here, this was my second job, almost left nursing
pros: Had amazing insurance for a single person.  It was like $4 a pay peroid for full coverage.  Needed a heart test done?  $25 for a co-pay and that was it.  Pills?  $8 for a months supply.  Then when I got married it jumped to $120 a pay period.  I'd consider this a lot of money because it was 10% of my take home pay for 40 hours of work as an RN!
cons: Over worked, underpaid.  I have a 4 year degree, worked there for 3 years and wasn't making $21.50 an hour.  I worked 325 hours of OT my first year, 400 of overtime my second and only brought home $41K.  Patient ratios are unsafe, 6-to-1 for nurses and 16-to-1 for CNAs.  I did hear that once I left, sometimes the ratio would be 7-to-1 and the nursing supervisor would tell staff "just deal with it."  Just deal with being charge, having 6 patients and offsites, and only making $21 an hour?  Never again.  I would work 5 days in a row, have one day off, then work then next 4 on.  On my days off, I would get text from my assistant manager telling me to "Quit ignoring me and come in" even though she never took patients.  She had no problem leaving at 3pm every Friday, but then they shoved it down our throats that Teamwork was a top priority and one of the 5 pillars of excellence.  This was an insane place to work.  I'd have my boss walk around talking about how money isn't important while I can't make ends meet as a nurse!  Advice is to NOT WORK AT NHRMC.  Oh, and because I left before my 5 years was up, I lost HALF of my vacation time I had earned while working there!  My new hospital HR told me that NHRMC policy of taking your vacation time if you leave early was piracy.  I almost quit nursing because NHRMC had such a stranglehold in the area.  I moved to the NorthWest of the country and my pay doubled and I only take 3-to-1!  Good riddance, NHRMC.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Sneads Ferry, NC
pros: Benefits, area discounts, job security, lasting friendships with co-workers, coastal living, pension plan, yearly raises (1-3%)
cons: Stress! Stress! Upper management, large medical center on small community hospital mindset, too big, communication on all levels, no breaks, no employee input

review_title: Too many chiefs not enough Indians!
pros: Team mates work together to provide patient care needs to the best of their ability. Benefits are above average. CEUs are provided in house. If you love working under pressure, this is a great place for you. You will find enormous growth in your multi tasking skills. You will find it easy to grow, because we learn from our mistakes and leadership hone in on any you make. Every department has a director, manager (or two), a coordinator (or two), so even tough you only have a few seasoned nurses on the floor either you, occasionally you can look forward to one the aforementioned chatting it up with your patients to reveal how behind you were delivering appropriate and safe care. It's so refreshing when your pulled from your duties to discuss those revelations so you can get further behind!
cons: If they would require ALL nurses with a leadership hat to wear a uniform, put their tablets down, their phones off, stop meeting and talking about how to get the herd to be more productive and get their fannies to the bedside to provide the care a nurse is trained to do then maybe life would be better for patients and staff. Never worked anywhere in the country that had so managers, assistants, coordinators and charge nurses. It's nuts. Fire them all and hire nurses to tend to patients. No one would miss any of them.

review_title: Harsh honesty, what the network doesn't want to hear or you to know.
pros: Decent benefits comparable to other facilities or organizations in the area. Decent camaraderie among junior staff members.
cons: Only hospital system in the county, largest employer for medical personnel. The Network has a monopoly on the health care field, which makes it almost the only place to work. HR lords over the company an acts on its' own rules an on its' own time. Junior staff is not appreciated, general feeling is that staff is a dime a dozen and can easily be replaced. As they are a monopoly, they are not concerned with employee satisfaction. There are no alternatives for employment, you either pretend to enjoy working for them or quickly find employment in a different field. The facilities themselves, are poor and in need of repair. Equipment is greatly outdated and unreliable, broken more often than working. When new construction or repairs are made to the facilities, they are not quality. Within days of new construction, brand new floors buckle and peel, paint staining and peeling off walls. While housekeeping attempts at upkeep, not enough staff means poor cleaning and not often enough. Layout of newly remodeled areas or newly built areas exhibit poor planning as necessary things are forgotten and patient flow is jumbled. The focus of senior management is patient satisfaction, while important, because of the over-focus of the network it gets in the way of staff providing basic care and functions. When senior management automatically tries to "recover" a bad customer experience or when someone complains, and management hastily gives gift cards or something similar to the individual without investigating the situation, creates a hostile work environment. As patients and their family members have come to learn if they complain they get rewarded and the staff reprimanded, even if the staff member was correct in their actions. Not only does it create a hostile work environment but not having the support of senior management damages employee morale.

review_title: The only option in this town
job_title: Certified Nurse Assistant in Wilmington, NC
pros: Taking care of people and helping others
cons:
Takes a long time to get hired
Some of the nurses are good but a lot of the younger ones talk awfully about patients
HR doesn't ever know what they are doing
No one wants to help you often

review_title: Worst company to work for. Corporate kiss at its highest level.
job_title: Patient Experience Representative in Wilmington, NC
pros: Benefits are good. Offers a gym to go to, but never get to utilize because your always working. Paid time off, as well hard to utilize since always short staffed.
cons: Everything else. Physician groups are completely backwards, not respect for employees. No empathy or rapport , should be centered around patient care and keeping employees happy, but instead it's all about revenue and and people walking around to get you in constant trouble.

review_title: Too many chiefs; not enough Indians
pros: Beautiful surroundings, competitive salaries, technologically savvy, fine reputation.
cons: Too many managers not on the same page. Too much conflict with co-workers and scheduling. Too many prima donna's.  Too many favorites.  Too much drama.

job_title: Professional Staff Nurse in Wilmington, NC
pros:
Healthcare benefits.
Floor orientation- preceptor and unit manager are very attentive and willing to help me learn and adjust as a new nurse on the floor.
cons: Pay- coming from Pittsburgh, the pay here is a good $5-7 less an hour... but the great benefits package makes up for it (I guess)

pros: Insurance was good, that's about it
cons: No empathy or rapport for anyone. The administrative individuals that was around with their clipboard and pen are the devil's advocates. They are so jealous and intimidated by young, smart, driven young women. They are also very racist, the upper management that is. Plus, the pay was horrible. Talk about slave work!

job_title: Behavioral Management Sitter in Wilmington, NC
pros: Pretty much everyone is friendly, pay is decent for the job.  There are pay increase increments for working night/weekend shifts.
cons: It's hard to get breaks, and it's a big environment, so getting used to it can be difficult when all of your fellow employees are busy and can't always walk you through certain things.

review_title: Great team experience, but needs improvement
pros: Good teamwork in my department, but some groups are overworked
cons: Some nepotism still exists in in hiring practices.  Performance of under-qualified people is not monitored.  Places heavier burden on others.

pros: PTO, staff,  benefits, hospital discounts, private building.
cons: Some Directors are not capable of being leaders and are threatened by their staff who appear motivated for growth.  These directors do not walk the walk; not leaders to look up to.

review_title: Treated  horrible by Co workers and management.
pros: Xmas bonus ,beach life, salary not bad, schedule not bad, half hour lunch, easy to get time off
cons: A lot of pushing new people around, talking behind backs, it's who you know or who likes you not what you know.

review_title: Experience at New Hanover Regional Medical Center
pros: close to the ocean. great weather.
cons: Salary does not compensate for work done.  Patient to nurse ratios are to high. Quality of Care can be compromised.

pros: Teaching Hospital-great physician's and PA's willing to teach.
cons: Horrible management. Lazy nursing staff.

pros: Excellent organization with strong leadership, committed and engaged employees, and positive financial viability.  Beautiful location on the coast of North Carolina close to beaches yet retaining a small town feel.
cons: None...great organization and well respect in community.

job_title: Support Associate III in Wilmington, NC
pros: It has great benefits and it is a good place to work.
cons: Sometimes it is hard to find time to be with family

review_title: Super busy teaching hospital - great people.
pros: Great co-workers, location, education, resources, technologically advance.
cons: Parking, expensive food on-campus, high nurse to patient ratios

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Wilmington, NC
pros: Awesome hospital with great patient care.  Great ceo
cons: The only negative I experienced was always the underhanded practices of the pharmacy management.

pros: Leader in patient care. Diligent in providing a broad range of services. Solid employer for the region. Company avoids layoffs.
cons: Some areas have very high time commitments and certain departments may tend to create burnout. Most areas have competent leaders.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Wilmington, NC
pros: Excellent place to work! Great pay, great benefits, beautiful sprawling facility.
cons: Scheduling conflicts, sometimes too many Chiefs in management.

job_title: Supply Chain Analyst in Wilmington, NC
pros: There were a lot of advancement opportunities, the company would consider advancing within first and then send outside.
cons: The pay was below average. That is why they wanted to advance within all of the time.

pros: Good benefits, state of the art technology
cons: Leadership lacks integrity, brown nosing is valued over merit; your job might be in jeopardy if you complain

pros: Everyone loves their job. People have been employed for years. Help is everywhere. Great company.
cons: Some jobs are monotonous. Almost everyone works off of work queues, which can get old after a while. All is important work, however.

pros: Great benefits, 24 hour gym, upper management really cares. They paid all their employees when we were out of work due to a direct hurricane hit.
cons: Individual departments are not all as healthy as the overall company.

pros: Strong leadership from CEO, with constant growth during recession. Plenty of available overtime. Low cost health insurance.
cons: Low pay. Consistently short staffed, then told that our productivity goal is not being met.

review_title: Great mission, great place to work.
pros: Great mission.  Really making a difference in the lives of people.  Staff is committed to the overall mission.
cons: Difficult to deal with the sadness that sometimes comes with the job.

review_title: My review for a ST is I love what I do. Please treat me the same!!!!
pros: great benefits, great hours, love what I do
cons: certified techs were given a market adjustment raise and not the non certified techs.

review_title: Horrible, worst nursing position I’ve ever had in 20 years
pros: Good insurance, nothing else really
cons: Horrible management, impossible patient visit ratio- expected to see 6 patients a day driving over 100 miles a day, lie about position hired for frequently and tell you to quit if you don’t like it .

pros: Flexible scheduele,working w the patients,outside support for employees in need
cons: Too many people playing god,gossiping,cliques,over priced food,understaffed,no room for growth,frowned upon by your work title

pros: Staff were really nice. Great experience for a student.
cons: You're kind of thrown into the deep end early on. Can be daunting to go up to patients/nurses/doctors at first.

pros: Great benefits, great schedule, great PDO accrual!
cons: Understaffed and overworked, too many chiefs and not enough indians, very expensive on-site cafeteria.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Wilmington, NC
pros: Benefits and get to choose on hours
cons: Patient/ CNA ratio night shift never sees mgt

review_title: Good for a job, not a career
job_title: Company Police Officer in Wilmington, NC
pros: Weekend pay is $1.50 on top of your regular pay. Lots of chances for overtime.
cons: Overtime is often mandatory because officers keep leaving.

job_title: Custormer Serves Representative in Wilmington, NC
pros: good benefits, pay vacation, health care is great.
cons: rules are for some and not for others

review_title: a company that does not care about the employee
pros: only hospital in an one hour radius.  They do employee the majority of people who live in the area.

job_title: Administrative Associate III in Wilmington, NC
pros: The hospital cares about the health and lifestyle of their employees.
cons: Things are a bit uncertain due to the partnership with Novant.

pros: Good resources from a teaching hospital
cons: Pay Is a little low but they offset it with so many benefits

review_title: Overall a good place to be

pros: Overtime available, good teamwork among nursing staff
cons: Management disorganized, they don't always advocate for staff

pros: Good large hospital for teaching and experience
cons: Sometimes too big employees get lost in processes and seen over business oriented lacking the personality of healthcare

pros: flexible schedule, great coworkers, great unit

pros: They do not value nurses. Leadership only gives management jobs to non nurses with MBA.

pros: EFC, Benefits, Main employers in New Hanover County

pros: Staff are some of the best friends you'll ever make
cons: Leadership is lacking among Management

pros: Great Company. Great team members to work with!

pros: I love my work family and environment!!
